#â€‹681 â€” March 28, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

JavaScript Visualized: Promise Execution â€” A helpful diagrammed and animated article, coupled with an (optional) 8-minute video, that goes into how promises work and are scheduled behind the scenes. Itâ€™s useful to have a good mental model of these mechanics, given promises form the basis of asynchronous functions in JavaScript.

Lydia Hallie

â–¶  Node.js: A Documentary of Its Origin Story â€” It's an hour long, but this documentary covers the history of Node particularly well, including how everything brewed up to the io.js fork of 2014. Easter weekend watching, perhaps?

Honeypot

Learn Advanced JavaScript Performance Optimization â€” Garbage collection, memory profiling, data structures like sets and arrays, and event loop management. Learn performance-driven programming, preparing you to write blazingly fast and efficient code!

Frontend Masters sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • The Node.js Technical Steering Committee has confirmed there's no intention to remove npm from the main Node distribution.

  • Is Bun Windows Yet? No, but Bun 1.1, which will support Windows, is supposedly just four days away..

  • An example of a simple, yet useful, Web Component in a single GitHub Gist.

  • The RedwoodJS framework now supports React Server Components too, as an alternative to its traditional GraphQL-based approach.

  • RunJS Play is a neat Web-based JavaScript playground that shows instant live feedback alongside each line.

  • Vercel now fully supports Node.js 20 for both builds and functions.

RELEASES:

  • VitePress 1.0 â€“ Powerful static site generator.

  • Neutralinojs 5.1 â€“ Alternative cross-platform desktop app framework.

  • Babylon.js 7.0 â€“ Powerful game & 3D rendering engine. No official release post yet, but expected later today.

  • Radix Themes 3.0 â€“ Powerful frontend component library.

  • Node.js v20.12.0 (LTS) and Node v18.20.0 (LTS).

  • Deno 1.42.0, Vite 5.2, TypeChat 0.1, Chromatic 3.

ğŸ“’ Articles & Tutorials

A Look at ECMAScript's Iterator Helper Methods â€” The proposal is several years old, but now at stage 3 in TC39, Iterator Helpers are being implemented and ship with V8 12.2/Chrome 122. The helpers are functions like .map, .filter, .take and .forEach and are made available to any object with Iterator.prototype in its prototype chain.

Rezvan Mahdavi Hezaveh (V8)

Introducing Waku's â€œPages Routerâ€ â€” Waku is an interesting minimal server-side React framework and itâ€™s now also bringing a minimal API to the modern React server components era: â€œMaking a Waku site is now as simple as making a few files and folders in the ./src/pages directoryâ€..

Sophia Andren

Transformational Auth & Identity | Userfront â€” Userfront is an auth & identity platform that transforms your business to serve free, freemium and enterprise customers.

Userfront sponsor

What You Need to Know About Modern CSS â€” A guide with a list of the newest additions to CSS (think nesting, view transitions, :has(), etc). JS plays an occasional role too, whether by enhancing or polyfilling modern CSS features.

Chris Coyier

Building a Micro HTMX SSR Framework â€” Matteo builds on an earlier tutorial about creating a â€˜movie quotesâ€™ app by exploring an alternative backend stack to use, based upon Fastify, Vite and HTMX.

Matteo Collina

Meet Angularâ€™s New output() API â€” Outputs allow component authors to emit values to parent components.
Paul Gschwendtner (Google)

We Rewrote our React App in Svelte in Three Weeks
Dusty Phillips

How to Use the Web Bluetooth API
Confidence Okoghenun

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Trix 2.1: A Clean, Rich WYSIWYG Editor for the Web â€” A WYSIWYG editor developed by the folks at 37signals (known as the birthplace of Ruby on Rails). Itâ€™s used in their Basecamp and HEY apps, so is about as stress tested as you can get. GitHub repo.

37signals

Meet the Future of Data Delivery with Hasura DDN â€” Join us April 16 for the unveiling of Hasura DDN. Create a unified, composable API, instantly and with no maintenance.

Hasura sponsor

Atlassian's Pragmatic Drag and Drop Framework â€” A performance-focused drag-and-drop library that can be used to power experiences on any frontend stack. Thereâ€™s a live demo on the page along with a recording of a talk by Alex Reardon walking through the motivations for creating it and how it works.

Atlassian

Create Vue3 App: A New Vue App Scaffolding Tool â€” Taking inspiration from tools like Create React App, this uses Vite to help you spin up a new Vue-based app using tools based upon answers you give to a number of questions.

Selemon Brahanu

<relative-time> 4.4: Format Timestamps as Localized Relative Times â€” Supply this web component with a standard formatted date and time and itâ€™ll render the right text to suit. It's actually used all over GitHub itself (use Inspect Element on commit times). Demo.

GitHub

DOM3D.js: 3D DOM Viewer in a GitHub Gist â€” Some code you can copy and paste into your browser console to get a 3D view of the DOM, sort of.. (move your pointer to navigate the.. thing it creates). The effect is odd but fun to play with.

Orion Reed

Free Auth for 1 Million MAUs â€” WorkOS provides easy-to-use APIs for authentication, user identity, and complex enterprise features like SSO and SCIM.

WorkOS sponsor

  • PGlite 0.1 â€“ Lightweight Postgres packaged as WASM into a TypeScript library for the browser, Node.js, Bun and Deno.

  • npm-publish 3.1 â€“ GitHub Action to publish packages to npm.

  • AdminJS 7.8 â€“ Automatic admin interface for Node.js apps.

  • Slonik 39.3 â€“ Node.js Postgres client with type safety.

  • react-three-fiber 8.16 â€“ React renderer for Three.js.

Ben Gubler

#â€‹679 â€” March 14, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Use Parcel Macros in Other Bundlers with unplugin-parcel-macros â€” Macros, as implemented in Parcel (and Bun!), are JS functions that run at build time whose results are inlined into a bundle in place of the original call. You can now use this feature with webpack, Vite, Rollup, esbuild, etc. Here's a quick example of how handy this can be.

Devon Govett

ğ• Devon goes into extra detail ğŸ¦ in this Twitter/X thread. You can also revisit the release of Parcel 2.12.0 to learn more.

How to Add an Onboarding Flow for your Application â€” Learn to enhance onboarding for your app with Clerk and Next.js: add custom session tokens, configure Next.js middleware for session data, and auto-update user metadata for a streamlined, code-efficient user experience with minimal code.

Clerk sponsor

Speedometer 3.0: The Best Way Yet to Measure Browser Performance â€” Speedometer has been around since 2014, but this new release is the first with a full collaborative approach involving each major browser engine (Blink, Gecko, WebKit). You can run the test yourself here.

Apple, Google, Microsoft, and Mozilla

WinterJS 1.0: A Fast WinterCG and WASM-Compatible JS Runtime â€” WinterJS initially pitched itself as a Rust and SpiderMonkey-powered â€˜Service Workers serverâ€™ but now simply boasts being the fastest WinterCG-compatible JavaScript web server full stop. The ability to run JITed JS workloads entirely under WebAssembly is next on their radar.

Wasmer

IN BRIEF:

  • Last week we linked to JSR, Deno's attempt at a new JavaScript registry. If that post was too much to digest, they now have â–¶ï¸ a 6-minute video introduction covering the key motivations and features.

  • The Astro folks have unveiled Astro DB, a fully managed SQL database designed exclusively for Astro.

  • ğŸ“Š Benchmarking Node vs LLRT/QuickJS.

  • f(x) is a fantastic terminal-based JSON viewer app (written in Go, but it can integrate with JS functions) â€“ its latest version supports YAML too.

RELEASES:

  • Biome 1.6 â€“ The toolchain gets partial support for Astro, Svelte & Vue files.

  • D3.js 7.9 â€“ Popular data visualization library. They launched a fantastic new homepage several months ago too, if you haven't checked in for a while.

  • React Native Skia 1.0 â€“ Complete with â–¶ï¸ a launch video.

  • Node.js v21.7.1, Cypress 13.7, Angular 17.3, Ember 5.7

ğŸ“’ Articles & Tutorials

Comparing JavaScript Frameworks: Templates â€” A thorough comparison of the template languages used by React, Vue, Angular and Svelte. Interesting analysis and this looks set to turn into a great series.

Maarten Hus

â–¶  Setting up an Express.js App with TypeScript in 2024 â€” This hour-long video isn't about building an entire app, but getting everything set up and working in a clear, easy to follow way, including a variety of modern DX niceties.

Anson the Developer

5 Lessons Design Systems Teams Can Learn from Open-Source Maintainers â€” Design system teams must balance evangelism with maintenance and development. Turns out, the same is true of open source.

StackBlitz sponsor

Make Your TypeScript Functions More Reusable with Generics â€” Matt kicks this off with a challenge for you to consider, before showing how to make a function more flexible and type-safe by using type parameters instead of any.

Matt Pocock

How HEAD Works in Git
Julia Evans

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Shiki 1.0: A Powerful Syntax Highlighter â€” A few months ago, we linked to Shikiji, a fork of Shiki that was created to push the project forward. Happily, the creators of both libraries decided to join forces and Shiki 1.0 was born. Itâ€™s a syntax highlighter based on TextMate grammar and themes, the same engine as used by VS Code. The docs are good.

Pine Wu, Anthony Fu

Rolldown: A Rust-Powered Bundler for JavaScript â€” A new entry to an increasingly crowded market, but they explain why theyâ€™re building it here â€“ itâ€™s intended to underpin a future bundler to be used in Vite, rather than esbuild and Rollup. GitHub repo.

Rolldown

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is the Future â€” 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints and console.log, supports Vitest, jest, karma, jasmine, and more.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Storybook 8 Released â€” The popular front-end component workshop introduces built-in visual testing, support for React Server Components, up to 50% faster start times, Vite 5 support, and upgraded Vue and React control auto-generation. Thereâ€™s also â–¶ï¸ a launch video to enjoy.

Michael Shilman (Storybook)

The Playwright Test Generator â€” I don't know why Iâ€™ve not linked this before, as itâ€™s so useful. Playwright isnâ€™t just a library for controlling browsers from JavaScript, but also includes a tool for generating tests and page navigation code from your own interactions. Hit record, do stuff, and code is written.

Microsoft

Managed Reliability & Observability for Webhooks & Asynchronous Messaging â€” Send, receive, authenticate, transform, filter, & route events between 3rd-party APIs (Stripe, Shopify, Twilio, etc.) & serverless functions.

Hookdeck sponsor

TinyBase 4.7: A Reactive Data Store for Local-First Apps â€” If you want a bit more database-esque structure around the management of state in your apps, this is worth a try. The demos show it off well. v4.7 adds support for Tursoâ€™s LibSQL (a fork of SQLite).

James Pearce et al.

âŒ˜K 1.0: A Composable, Unstyled 'Command Menu' for React Apps â€” The home page includes some neat examples in a variety of styles. GitHub repo.

Paco Coursey

webtoon/PSD: Zero-Dependency PSD Parser for Browsers and Node â€” PSD (Photoshop Document) is the format used by Photoshop and this library lets you dig into metadata and pixels on each image layer.

webtoon inc

  • Knip 5.1 â€“ Find unused files, dependencies and exports.

  • React Date Picker 6.3 â€“ Simple date picker component. (Demo.)

  • OverlayScrollbars 2.6 â€“ JavaScript custom scrollbars plugin.

  • ğŸ—“ date-fns 3.4 â€“ Modern JavaScript date utility library.

  • Slonik 37.3 â€“ Node.js Postgres client with type safety.

  • MQTT.js 5.4 â€“ MQTT client for Node and browsers.

  • Perspective 2.9 â€“ Fast visualization of streaming datasets.

  • Rspack 0.5.7 â€“ Fast Rust-based web bundler.
